docs.lead_paragraph: The plans are making a comeback, but they are so tainted by their poor reputation that insurers and companies try to avoid calling them H.M.O.s.

headline.main: Trying to Revive H.M.O.s, but Without Those Scarlet Letters
headline.print_headline: H.M.O.s Make a Comeback,  Despite Stigma

docs.abstract: Health maintenance organizations are returning to prominence, moving past their reputation as symbol of all that is wrong with health insurance; insurers are eager to bring back features that restrict choices of doctors or hospitals as way to cut costs.
docs.snippet: The plans are making a comeback, but they are so tainted by their poor reputation that insurers and companies try to avoid calling them H.M.O.s.

keywords.value: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: These banking fees are borne by ordinary consumers, disproportionately by the poorest among them, and many miss details tucked into fine print.

headline.main: Overdraft Practices Continue to Gut Bank Accounts and Haunt Customers
headline.print_headline: Debts Pile Up  as Banks Bill  for Overdrafts

docs.abstract: Financial regulation has failed to address problem of bank overdraft practices, which consumer advocates say often mire consumers in unintended debt; despite litigation, consumer anger and public concern on part of lawmakers, banks continue to rake in money from overdraft frees, which totaled $11 billion for nation's large consumer banks in 2015, or about 8 percent of big banks' profits.
docs.snippet: These banking fees are borne by ordinary consumers, disproportionately by the poorest among them, and many miss details tucked into fine print.

byline.original: By MICHAEL CORKERY and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
